audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker describing activities at the Max Planck Institute for Chemistry and Mainz, specifically "blasting diamonds" during research on superconductivity. The speaker, with a non-American accent, estimates the number of diamonds broken per year, from "50-100 diamonds" and poses the question "for what?". The same speaker indicates their goal of metallic hydrides needing high pressures and a lot of diamonds, also that the metallic hydrogen is interesting because of predicted high-temperature superconductivity. The speaker ends by saying, "For me, yeah," speaking casually.

The clip features a single male speaker, who is speaking in an informative tone about electricity and superconductivity, noting that "we live in a world of electricity." He highlights the interesting phenomenon of superconductivity, where electricity flows without any loss. His tone suggests he believes that "if mankind will use superconductivity," it could be a dramatically world-changing technology. After the speaker finishes, a second male voice says "The effort is well worth it," in a slightly lower register.

The clip opens with a narrator, speaking in a clear, informative tone, discussing energy loss in Germany and the research on superconductivity at the Max Planck Institute, envisioning a material that is "superconductive at room temperature." Following the narrator, a male voice with an accent explains that superconductivity has always been "linked to lower temperatures," that is "unpractical," and only after "fifty years" scientists are understanding "the phenomena of superconductivity."

The audio begins with a male speaker providing a historical context about superconductivity, mentioning its discovery in 1911 and the subsequent development of a theoretical foundation. He refers to the Bardeen-Cooper-Schrieffer theory.  Another male speaker then poses a question about the "highest critical temperature" of superconductivity, wondering about the possibility of "room temperature superconductivity." He mentions a recent finding of superconductivity at -73 degrees, noting it's a temperature found in nature. The audio transitions, with him continuing to ask about finding "good superconductors."  There are no discernible background sounds or music throughout the clip.

The audio clip features a male speaker, seemingly in an educational setting, discussing elements in the periodic table, specifically hydrogen and its potential for superconductivity. He refers to the first column of the periodic system, alkaline metals, and states that, "from theoretical point of view, this is ideal case to find superconductivity". His tone is informative and academic. Following this explanation, the clip continues with a second male speaker, who summarizes that while it seems surprising, hydrogen belongs to the same group as lithium and sodium, and was expected to have similar characteristics. This is followed by a musical interlude, the style of which I cannot identify, before the clip ends.

The clip begins with a male speaker discussing hydrogen, explaining that it is not a metal, but can become one at very high pressures, around "three, four megabars", similar to the pressure at the Earth's core. He states that reaching this pressure is now available in the laboratory. The same male speaker notes that the equipment used to achieve this high pressure is surprisingly unspectacular and portable.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing an experimental setup involving a "cell" containing a "sample" squeezed between "two diamond anvils" to produce "very high pressure", though this comes at the cost of a "small sample". He speaks in a clear, measured tone, seemingly describing a scientific process. The speaker's tone shifts to one of excitement, with the researchers "successfully prov[ing] that hydrogen has the characteristics of a superconductor", namely "very low resistance under very high pressure."

The clip begins with a male speaker questioning why diamonds break easily despite being a hard material. He mentions imperfections and cracks, which lead to breakage. High pressure and stress contribute to this. This is followed by an announcement about finding out about superconductors. Then, there's the sound of speech which cuts off abruptly.

The audio clip begins with an inquisitive-sounding male voice explaining a scientist's discovery. He transitions into clarifying the concept of conductivity and superconductivity, accompanied by background music that is calm and scientific. Another male voice, speaking in a slightly accented manner, states, "electrical current goes through copper wires," adding that "there is electrical resistance and a lot of losses, even in copper for electricity." The first speaker then returns, describing copper as a good conductor, while elaborating on how the atoms conduct electricity. He concludes that in ordinary conductors, resistance slows down the current.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that Dr. Arametz and his team discovered that hydrogen can acquire metallic characteristics and conduct electricity like copper. The speaker has a formal tone. A second male speaker with a slightly accented voice then elaborates on the process, explaining that hydrogen transforms into atomic hydrogen under high pressure, causing electrons to become free and enabling it to conduct electricity, similar to copper.

The clip starts with a male speaker discussing finding "really high superconductivity", particularly highlighting metallic hydrogen and hydrides, mentioning sulfur hydride as an interesting find. He explains that sulfur ions in metallic hydride attract hydrogen atoms, stabilizing the structure. A narrator then speaks in a neutral tone about molecular changes in hydrogen sulfide observed at high pressure and low temperature. He specifies the formation of Cooper electrons and their ability to conduct electricity without resistance.

The audio clip begins with a male speaker discussing hydrogen sulfide's superconductivity and a new world record set in 2015. He states that hydrogen sulfide becomes a superconductor at a temperature of -70 degrees and under "pressure of...". The clip ends abruptly before the sentence is completed. His tone is informative.

The clip opens with a male speaker stating "1.5 million bar." He proceeds with a factual tone, discussing future research, specifically looking for room temperature superconductivity, and the easiest way to achieve this is with high pressure. He then explains starting work on searching for materials with high temperature superconductivity without pressure. A narrator, also male, then summarizes the benefits of this research, mentioning nuclear fusion, high-speed trains, and the potential to increase computer chip speeds significantly. The clip concludes with the narrator saying the search for more superconductors continues, aiming to turn the dream of room-temperature superconductivity into reality.
